Iridium (Ir) demonstrates exceptional properties in CO2 hydrogenation reactions, yet the reaction mechanism remains unclear. Utilizing Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, the reaction mechanism on the Ir/Ni (111) surface has been investigated. Mulliken charge analysis indicates that CO2 is securely adsorbed and activated on the Ir/Ni (111) surface, forming CO2*, which is crucial for the subsequent hydrogenation process. By evaluating both the reaction energy barrier and the heat of reaction, the optimal methanation pathway CO2*→ COOH*→ CO*→ HCO*→ HCOH*→ CH*→ CH2*→ CH3*→ CH4* has been identified. The step of hydrogenation leading to HCO* is recognized as the rate-determining step in methanation, displaying the highest reaction activation energy. Furthermore, a greater energy barrier for C* formation proves advantageous in enhancing anti-carbon deposition properties and prolonging catalyst lifespan. Concurrently, the capability for C* hydrogenation sees dynamic and thermodynamic improvements, potentially augmenting the catalyst's methanation performance. Introduction The unchecked exploitation of fossil fuels as a primary energy source has led to a significant rise in atmospheric carbon dioxide levels, subsequently intensifying the greenhouse effect, which challenges the sustainable progress of human society [1–3]. However, this perspective can be shifted by viewing CO2 as a readily available and economical substrate for producing valuable fine chemicals such as CO, HCOOH, and CH4. Such a conversion not only mitigates environmental impacts but also offers avenues for renewable energy sources [4–6]. Notably, the hydrogenation of CO2 to yield methane (CH4) emerges as a viable conversion strategy. Methane, being a primary constituent of natural gas, serves as an efficient and eco-friendly fuel [7–11]. The high symmetry and robust C = O bond in carbon dioxide hinder its activation [12]. Consequently, exploring efficient catalysts for CO2 methanation has garnered significant attention [13]. Although Ni stands out as a promising catalyst for CO2 methanation owing to its catalytic hydrogenation activity, it grapples with issues like carbon deposition and limited selectivity at reduced temperatures [14]. Noble metals such as Pt, Pd, and Au manifest enhanced hydrogenation activity during CO2-to-CH4 conversion and exhibit anti-carbon deposition properties. Nevertheless, their broad-scale industrial application is curtailed by their prohibitive cost and the scarce availability of raw materials [15]. Research indicates that integrating second metals into Ni catalysts could diminish coke formation during CO2 hydrogenation, thereby prolonging catalyst lifespan and bolstering its stability [16–18]. Xiaotao Liang et al. [19] probed the CO2 hydrogenation process on Ni-Ru (111) and ascertained that Ru-doping not only markedly attenuates the adsorption energy of O* (−5.35 eV), shielding the Ni site from oxidation but also amplifies resistance to carbon deposition by escalating the activation energy barrier for all surface C* formation reactions. Zhiliang Ou et al. [20] discerned that Pt metal doping effectively curtails carbon deposition by raising the reaction barrier against coke formation. Furthermore, the Pt-Ni (111) catalyst augments C* hydrogenation, which further mitigates surface carbon deposition. Frequently employed in hydrogenation procedures, such as olefin and unsaturated aldehyde hydrogenation [21–26], Ir's unoccupied d orbital enhances CO2 binding and curtails H + reduction during reactions [25,27]. Jiaqi Bai et al.'s [28] study revealed that the superior hydrogenation activity of Ni-Ir/SiO2, relative to the monometallic Ir-SiO2 and Ni-SiO2 catalysts, is due to the genesis of Ni-Ir bimetallic alloys. This bimetallic system synergy facilitates efficient reactant adsorption and electron transfer, thereby diminishing reaction activation energy and accelerating the reaction rate. In parallel, Yunxiang Tang et al. [29] formulated a hybrid material, Ir@UIO-66, and identified that under illumination, the excited electrons in the UIO-66 structure undergo efficient separation and transfer, supported by Ir NPs. This process amplifies H2 cleavage and CO2 activation, with the Ir NPs environment aiding in the activation and conversion of HCOO species, ultimately elevating methane yield and selectivity. Additionally, Liang Wang et al. [30] synthesized an Ir-Ni (111)/SiO2 catalyst featuring diminutive and uniformly dispersed metal particles using a self-confinement approach. They found that Ir-doping thwarts metal surface agglomeration, and the pronounced enhancement in bimetallic synergy boosts reaction conversion efficiency while mitigating the influence of carbon deposits. Lingna Liu et al. [31] observed that Ir-doping on the Cu (111) catalyst surface favors the COOH→CO→HCO reaction sequence, with spontaneous H2 dissociation on the surface, ensuring abundant hydrogen for the CO2 hydrogenation process. Despite the commendable efficacy of Ir-Ni in hydrogenation reactions, the design of stable bimetallic catalysts and the establishment of catalytic sites are hindered by an ambiguous catalytic surface reaction mechanism and reactant adsorption strength. To address this, the first principle calculation method has been employed to ascertain the adsorption energy of both reactants and products, along with the reaction energy barriers and reaction heats for fundamental processes. Most crucially, a combination of dynamic mechanics and thermodynamics has been applied to pinpoint the optimal reaction pathway on Ir/Ni (111), laying the groundwork for further advancements in bimetallic catalyst development. Computational details All spin-polarized DFT computations were executed using the DMol3 code [32,33]. The reaction activation energy was determined utilizing the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) combined with the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) method to elucidate the effects of electronic exchange [34,35]. A 2 × 2 × 1 k-point mesh, based on the Monkhorst-Pack technique, was employed for the Brillouin-zone integration [36]. For estimating the energy of transition state structures in CO2 hydrogenation, methodologies including linear synchronous transit (LST) and quadratic synchronous transit (QST), in conjunction with a mode-eigenvector, were implemented [37,38]. Given that the catalyst is of magnetic nature and consists of Ni, computations for different orbits utilized the spin limitless option, with multiplicity set to Auto to assess the ground state spin via spin restriction. The primary focus of this study was the Ir/Ni (111) surface. For modeling the Ir/Ni (111) catalysts, a four-layer plate was constructed, with doping in the first layer. The model was established using (3 × 3) surface unit cells. Furthermore, a 15 Å vacuum region in the z direction was incorporated to minimize interactions between adjacent layers. Prior to geometric optimization, the third and fourth layers had constrained coordinates. The first and second layers were permitted to relax, during which Ni atoms on the surface were substituted by Ir atoms. As depicted in Fig. 1 , eight distinct adsorption sites—Ni-top, Ir-top, Ni-fcc, Ir-fcc, Ni-bri, Ir-bri, Ni-hcp, and Ir-hcp—were considered for the adsorption of each species. The adsorption energy, represented by Eads, quantifies the interaction between the reactant adsorbate and the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst surface. It is computed using the equation: E ads = E absorbate + slab − E absorbate − E slab where Eabsorbate+slab is the combined energy of the reactant on the surface, Eabsorbate is the energy of isolated adsorbates, and Eslab indicates the energy of the unoccupied surface. The heat of reaction, ΔE, for each process is given by: ΔE=EFS−EIS. Here, IS denotes the initial state with its total energy being EIS, TS signifies the transition state with its energy as EFS, and FS, the final state, has the energy EFS. Utilizing the Gibbs equation:ΔG=ΔH−TΔS, where ΔG is the system's free energy change, ΔH denotes the system's enthalpy change, T is the temperature, and ΔS is the entropy change. Given the molecular-level focus of this study, the effects of temperature and entropy changes on reactions are disregarded, positing that the reaction enthalpy on the catalyst surface approximates the Gibbs free energy. Results and discussion Reactant structure and adsorption energy on the Ir/Ni (111) surface On the catalyst surface, the adsorption site exhibiting the most negative Eads value is considered energetically favorable for adsorption. The configuration corresponding to this site demonstrates the most stable adsorption characteristics. The optimal adsorption conformation and energy for all intermediates are detailed in Fig. 2 . Table 1 presents the Eads values for the most stable adsorption sites. On the Ni-bri sites, OH* and CO* exhibit Eads values of −0.98 eV and −1.35 eV, respectively. C* is adsorbed on the Ni-bridge site with an adsorption energy of −2.92 eV, which is substantially higher than the adsorption energy of pure Ni (111) with Ea=−7.94 eV. This suggests limited accumulation of C* on the catalyst surface. O* possesses a weaker adsorption energy compared to the Ni1W (111) value of −6.83 eV [39], inferring that the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst is resistant to oxidation. COOH* achieves optimal adsorption at the Ir-top site via the C-Ir bond, with an Eads value of −1.47 eV, while COHOH* prefers the Ir-top position, registering an Eads of −1.77 eV. Regarding HxCO (x = 1 − 3) species, the advancing hydrogenation process reveals these species predominantly attach to the catalyst through O atoms. The stable adsorption energies for H2CO* and H3CO* stand at −0.77 eV and −0.97 eV, respectively. For HxCOH (x = 0 − 3) species, COH* is anchored by the C atom at the Ir-Fcc location, demonstrating an Eads value of −2.14 eV. HCOH* occupies the Ni-Bri site, binding to the catalyst via the C atom with an adsorption strength of −1.87 eV. Calculations reveal a decreasing adsorption strength for HxCOH (x = 0–3) species with increasing H atom count. For CHx(x = 1–4) species, Ni-Fcc serves as the optimal site for CH* with an Eads of −3.18 eV. CH2* and CH3* primarily occupy the Bridge and Top sites, yielding Eads values of −2.15 eV and −1.09 eV, respectively. CH4* gravitates towards the Ni-Top site and exhibits relatively weak adsorption. Results indicate that as hydrogenation progresses, the affinity of CHx* species for the Ir/Ni (111) surface diminishes. Given its bond energy of 0.54 eV, CH4* is poised to readily desorb from the Ir/Ni (111) surface, enhancing catalyst selectivity. To elucidate the enhancement in catalytic performance following the doping of Ir atoms, Mulliken charges on the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst surface were computed pre- and post-CO2 adsorption. As presented in Fig. 3 (a)(b), the integration of Ir leads to the accumulation of surface charge on the catalyst, promoting subsequent CO2 adsorption and activation. Upon adsorption, CO2* acquires a charge of 0.237 eV from the Ir/Ni (111) surface. This charge transfer triggers a deviation in the CO2 molecule from its primary linear geometry; consequently, the OC-O bond angle undergoes alteration, adopting a bifurcated CO2 adsorption structure [40]. Concurrently, there is an elongation of the C = O bond; specifically, the two C = O bonds extend from 1.179 Å to 1.272 Å and 1.250 Å [41]. This elongation is synonymous with a decrease in bond energy, favoring the hydrogenation of CO2, as depicted in (Fig. 3 (d).). From the partial state density (PDOS) waveform presented in Fig. 4 , a marked spin-orbit interaction between CO2 and the Ir/Ni (111) surface becomes evident. This interaction is characterized by a substantial overlap between the d-orbitals of the Ni atom and the p-orbitals of the O atom, spanning from −9.41 eV to −0.31 eV, denoting stable adsorption. When juxtaposed with Ni (111), the d-band center of Ir/Ni (111) is −0.31 eV, slightly elevated compared to Ni (111) at −0.32 eV. This distinction suggests that the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst possesses enhanced activity. Computational findings disclose an adsorption energy of CO2* at −0.67 eV, notably less than those observed for Ru-Ni (111) (−0.29 eV), Ni2Fe (111) (−0.02 eV), and Ni (111) (−0.40 eV), implying a more stable adsorption of CO2 on the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst surface [19,42,43]. Collectively, these results unambiguously indicate that CO2* is stably anchored and considerably activated on the Ir/Ni (111) surface, thereby promoting the ensuing hydrogenation process. Reaction pathway of CO2 hydrogenation In this section, the mechanism of the CO2 methanation reaction occurring on the Ir-Ni (111) surface was thoroughly examined, and a corresponding reaction path diagram was constructed, as depicted in Fig. 5 . To elucidate the detailed process of CO2 hydrogenation on the Ir/Ni (111) surface, the transition states (TS) of all fundamental reactions were identified to determine the activation energy (Ea) and change in energy (ΔE), which are detailed in Table 2 . CO2* hydrogenation and dissociation Based on previously reported research, three main reaction pathways for the conversion of CO2-to-CH4 have been proposed. As illustrated in Fig. 6 , CO2* hydrogenation can proceed via two distinct reaction pathways. In one pathway, the H atom interacts with the O* atom of CO2* to yield COOH* (R2). In contrast, in the second pathway, the H atom targets the C* atom of CO2* to produce HCOO* (R3). Additionally, CO2* can dissociate into CO* and O*(R4) by obtaining free electrons. According to Ellen B. Sterk et al. [44], the methanation reaction on pure Ni (111) surface is a greater probability to directly dissociate CO2 into CO* and O*. Yonghao Feng et al. [45] calculated the CO2 hydrogenation reaction on the surface of M@Cu (211) (M = Y, Fe, Co, Ni, Zn, Ru, Rh, Ag, Au, Pd and Pt) and discovered that the second metal's doping makes CO2 more amenable to hydrogenation to produce COOH*, primarily because the hydrogenation rate is higher than the rate of C = O bond rupture. Evaluation of the reaction energy barriers and reaction heat of the three pathways in this study reveals that the Ea for COOH* formation is 1.07 eV, with an exothermic value of 0.01 eV. Both dynamic and thermodynamic analyses favor the production of COOH*. COOH* hydrogenation and dissociation As shown in Fig. 7 , COOH* can be converted through three different processes: hydrogenation to produce COHOH*(R5), HCOOH*(R6), and dissociation to produce CO* and OH* (R7). COOH* dissociates to CO* and OH* with less energy than R5 and R6, demonstrating a preference for dissociation over hydrogenation. Furthermore, the hydrogenation process is endothermic, and the dissociation of COOH* requires exothermic 0.03 eV. The dissociation is advantageous from a thermodynamic perspective. CO* hydrogenation and dissociation CO* may undergo hydrogenation to form either COH* or HCO*, or dissociate to yield C* and O*. R8 describes the combination of H* with the O atom to yield COH*, while R9 illustrates the association of H* and C atoms to produce HCO* (Fig. 8 ). Notably, R9 presents a substantial reaction energy barrier (Ea = 3.19 eV), posing challenges for heat absorption. Computational analysis reveals that R7 and R8 possess activation energy barriers of 1.45 eV and 1.24 eV, respectively. Thus, hydrogenating CO* to derive HCO* emerges as the most favorable route from both dynamic and thermodynamic perspectives. COH* hydrogenation and dissociation H* can associate with the C atoms of COH* to yield HCOH* (R11), or COH* might dissociate into C* and OH* (R12) (Fig. 8). Direct dissociation of COH* is deemed challenging due to its requisite heat absorption (0.59 eV) and a reaction energy barrier (1.80 eV) higher than that for hydrogenation. While the formation of HCOH* is an exothermic reaction (ΔE=−0.60 eV), it displays a reduced energy barrier compared to R12 (Ea=1.11 eV). Analyses grounded in dynamics and thermodynamics suggest a greater propensity for COH* to hydrogenate, leading to HCOH*. HCO* hydrogenation and dissociation As depicted in Fig. 8, H* can interact with HCO* to produce HCOH*(R14) or H2CO*(R15) depending on whether it associates with the O or C atoms. Moreover, HCO* can dissociate upon electron acquisition, resulting in CH* and O* (R26). According to Ellen B. Sterk et al. [44], the reaction is a Speed-determining step for the dissociation of HCO* into CH* and O* for Ni (111). Computational insights indicate that R14 confronts a marginally smaller energy barrier (1.16 eV) than R15 (1.17 eV) and R26 (1.80 eV), implying a higher probability of forming HCOH* during hydrogenation of the O atom in HCO*. The aforementioned findings suggest that the addition of Ir as second mental decreases the intermolecular interaction between HCO* and the catalyst surface, enhances the bond energy of the CO bond, and facilitates the formation of HCOH* by promoting the combination of O* and H*. HCOH* hydrogenation and dissociation R16 involves the amalgamation of H* and HCOH* to produce H2COH*, while R17 seeks to yield CH* and OH* from HCOH* upon electron incorporation (Fig. 9 ). Remarkably, dissociating into CH* demands a lesser energy barrier compared to the hydrogenation, with respective reaction activation barriers for R16 and R17 at 1.40 eV and 1.14 eV. Consequently, the dissociation of HCOH* to form CH* and OH* is deemed more feasible. H2CO* hydrogenation Two distinct hydrogenation pathways exist for H2CO*: hydrogenation of the O atom yielding H2COH* (R18) or hydrogenation of the C atom leading to H3CO* (R19). Evaluations indicate that overcoming energy barriers of 1.27 eV and 1.78 eV are required for R18 and R19, respectively. Moreover, R17 is endothermic with a heat absorption of 0.22 eV, while R18 is exothermic, releasing 0.41 eV. From a dynamic perspective, H2CO* tends to hydrogenate to form H2COH* more readily. H2COH* hydrogenation and dissociation H2COH* can either directly dissociate to yield CH2* and OH* (R20) or undergo hydrogenation to produce CH3OH* (R21). Energy barrier calculations reveal that R20 possesses a relatively lower barrier of 1.20 eV, favoring the dissociation of the C = O bond to produce CH2* and OH* over the hydrogenation process leading to H3COH* (R21). Consequently, methanol synthesis dynamics are more intricate, suggesting that the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst surface augments the selectivity towards methane production. Hydrogenation of CH* involves sequential reactions R22, R23, and R24, leading to CH4*. Analysis of optimal adsorption structures revealed that the Ni site predominantly hosts CHx hydrogenation, with activation energies for R22, R23, and R24 being 1.00 eV, 1.07 eV, and 0.59 eV, respectively. Throughout the hydrogenation progression, the adsorption energies of CH*, CH2*, CH3*, and CH4* consistently diminish, thereby enhancing the catalyst's selectivity towards CH4*. Reaction heats for R22, R23, and R24 are recorded at −0.49 eV, −0.70 eV, and −0.98 eV, respectively. The sequential increase in reaction heat signifies augmented product stability. In essence, continuous hydrogenation of CH* is beneficial for methane production. The most effective route for CO2 methanation on the Ir-Ni (111) surface is depicted in Fig. 10 . Anti-carbon deposition property Catalyst deactivation stems from C* formation on the catalyst surface due to side reactions. This formation diminishes the effective catalytic area, leading to a progressive loss in catalyst activity. Side reactions contributing to C* formation, including R10, R13, R25 and R26, are illustrated in Fig. 11 . In R10, CO* converts into C* and O* upon acquiring free electrons; however, this step encounters a substantial reaction energy barrier (Ea = 3.19 eV), making it a less probable reaction. R13 is an endothermic reaction requiring a 1.80 eV energy barrier to dissociate COH* into C* and OH*. Both kinetically and thermodynamically, this process proves more challenging than the reactions on Ni (111) as discussed in literature K. The computed reaction energy signifies that the aforementioned four reactions are endothermic. Their Ea values substantially exceed those on the Ni (111) surface. The higher energy demand for these side reactions indicates that coke formation over the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst is both thermodynamically and kinetically discouraged [46,47]. The hydrogenation of CH* is dynamically more feasible than its dissociation (CH* + * → C* + H*, Ea = 1.94 eV; CH* + H* → CH2* + *, Ea = 1.00 eV), implying the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst's augmented resistance against carbon deposition. Moreover, the exothermic nature of the C hydrogenation reaction on the catalyst surface (R27: C* + H* → CH* + *, Ea= −1.33 eV) combined with its lower activation energy (Ea=0.45 eV) suggests the likelihood of C hydrogenating to CH* over carbon deposition. This further infers the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst's enhanced capability in promoting methanation, minimizing C* production, and Conclusions In the present study, DFT calculations are employed to delineate the CO2 hydrogenation reaction pathway on the Ir/Ni (111) surface. All potential species involved in the process were subjected to optimization for ideal adsorption structures, followed by corresponding adsorption energy calculations. Through Mulliken charge and PDOS analysis, findings indicate that CO2 achieves successful activation and adsorption on the Ir/Ni (111) surface, enhancing the efficiency of subsequent reactions. The evolution of CH3OH and CH4 demands activation energies of 1.92 eV and 1.24 eV, respectively, underlining the catalyst's exceptional selectivity for methanation. The most viable pathway for CO2 methanation on the Ir/Ni (111) surface, as inferred from calculations incorporating reaction energy barriers and reaction heat, proceeds as: CO2*→ COOH*→ CO*→ HCO*→ HCOH*→ CH*→ CH2*→ CH3*→ CH4*. Moreover, the hydrogenation reaction involving C* proves more conducive than its carbon deposition counterpart. The formation of CH* plays a pivotal role in methane generation. These findings lay a foundational understanding of the CO2 hydrogenation reaction mediated by bimetallic catalysts and offer theoretical insight for the design of such catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Iridium (Ir) demonstrates exceptional properties in CO2 hydrogenation reactions, yet the reaction mechanism remains unclear. Utilizing Density Functional Theory (DFT) calculations, the reaction mechanism on the Ir/Ni (111) surface has been investigated. Mulliken charge analysis indicates that CO2 is securely adsorbed and activated on the Ir/Ni (111) surface, forming CO2*, which is crucial for the subsequent hydrogenation process. By evaluating both the reaction energy barrier and the heat of reaction, the optimal methanation pathway CO2*→ COOH*→ CO*→ HCO*→ HCOH*→ CH*→ CH2*→ CH3*→ CH4* has been identified. The step of hydrogenation leading to HCO* is recognized as the rate-determining step in methanation, displaying the highest reaction activation energy. Furthermore, a greater energy barrier for C* formation proves advantageous in enhancing anti-carbon deposition properties and prolonging catalyst lifespan. Concurrently, the capability for C* hydrogenation sees dynamic and thermodynamic improvements, potentially augmenting the catalyst's methanation performance.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical research the mechanism on the Ir/Ni (111) catalyst surface for CO2 methanation reaction
